MS MCQs

    Settle competing commits by using merge conflict resolution on GitHub

    »

    1. Which of the following statements about merges is false?

      Files added on the compare branch can be merged into the base branch if they don’t yet exist there.

      Edits to lines of code on the compare branch can be merged if those same lines haven’t changed on the base branch since the compare branch was last pulled.

      When a merge completes successfully, it ensures that your changes didn’t break the build.


    2. Why are merge conflicts bad?

      The base branch becomes unstable until the conflicts are resolved. As a result, associated builds probably won’t succeed.

      This is a trick question. Merge conflicts aren’t bad; they’re an inevitable part of distributed version control.

      Merge conflicts are embarrassing for the offending developer because everyone will think they were careless.


    3. What is the best way to avoid most complex merge conflicts?

      Regularly pull updates your branch.

      Only pull updates for the base branch onto your branch immediately before creating a pull request.

      Open a pull request as soon as you create your branch. This transparency will help everyone else understand your proposed changes so they don’t merge any competing code before you do.
